awd_titl_txt: Research Initiation Award: Investigation of Coherent Elastic Neutrino-Nucleus Scattering
awd_abstract_narration:
The Historically Black Colleges and Universities-Undergraduate Program (HBCU-UP) Research Initiation Awards (RIAs) provide support to STEM junior faculty at HBCUs who are starting to build a research program, as well as for mid-career faculty who may have returned to the faculty ranks after holding an administrative post or who needs to redirect and rebuild a research program. Faculty members may pursue research at their home institution, at an NSF-funded Center, at a research intensive institution or at a national laboratory. The RIA projects are expected to help further the faculty member's research capability and effectiveness, to improve research and teaching at his or her home institution, and to involve undergraduate students in research experiences. With support from the National Science Foundation, North Carolina Central University (NCCU) will conduct research in coherent elastic neutrino-nucleus scattering and formalize participation in the COHERENT research collaboration whose objective is to measure this type of neutrino scattering.  This scattering was predicted in 1974, but has not yet been observed. Once observed, the methods and results will have an impact on research in astrophysics.  This project will provide valuable physics research experience and mentorship for several minority undergraduate students at North Carolina Central University and also during their summers at Duke University.  The project will bring cutting-edge research and research techniques into the NCCU classroom. In addition, the project will help North Carolina Central University build its research capacity and enhance the educational and research experiences of their undergraduate students.  

The objective of this project is to participate in the deployment and data acquisition of detector systems and to perform data analysis and simulations of coherent elastic neutrino-nucleus scattering (CENNS) measurements and associated background studies on key nuclear targets (such as Germanium) and shielding materials (including lead).  The COHERENT collaboration will take advantage of recent advances in detector technology and the availability of an intense source of pulsed neutrinos available as a byproduct of the Spallation Neutron Source at the Oak Ridge National Laboratory (ORNL) to carry out the first CENNS investigation. The immediate COHERENT goal is to compare CENNS measurements in selected nuclei to Standard Model cross section calculations to test for neutrino non-standard interactions. In addition, the measured reaction rates have direct implications for understanding detector response and background in dark-matter experiments, and for modeling supernova processes and detection. Collaborators include Duke University faculty at the Triangle Universities Nuclear Laboratory (TUNL) and the Oak Ridge National Laboratory.

por.por_cntn:
Scientific Advancement:

The COHERENT collaboration reported the first observation of coherent elastic neutrino-nucleus scattering (CEvNS) in a CsI target. This project supported NCCU to construct a detector to measure CEvNS from NaI.

An array of 24 repurposed sodium iodide (NaI) crystals comprise the NaI neutrino Experiment (NaIvE) with 185 kg of detector mass.  Deployed in 2016, this array took data that determined the backgrounds were low showing the feasibility to measure the low-energy CEvNS recoil signal. In 2017, muon veto panels constructed by NCCU student Abasi Brown was added to the NaIvE detector allowing high-energy, inelastic neutrino scattering signals to be measured with a reduced muon background.   A multi-ton, NaI detector array was designed, including a new electronics base that allows two signals (low-energy CEvNS and high-energy inelastic scattering) to be measured simultaneously.

The multi-ton detector modular design was completed.  The dual-gain base design was completed and tested.  Setbacks resulting from the pandemic and financial constraints delayed the construction of the modules and bases.  At the time of the final report, the modules were under construction and the electronic boards were printed with students and the PI constructing the bases.  The multi-ton array will begin deployment in spring 2022.

Professional development: 

PI D. Markoff was promoted to full Professor in Spring 2018 based in part on this grant award.

Dr. Markoff became the lead convener in 2018 for the NaI detector projects in the COHERENT collaboration.

Eight NCCU undergraduate students participated on the project, with most of the students participating for a year or more. Six out of the eight students were African-American, and two were women.  Five students attended at least one conference and presented a poster, with some students attending more than one conference.  Two students completed a senior thesis project and written report based on their work for the NaI detector projects.

Three students went on to attend a bridge to Ph.D. program (Fisk, OSU, Wash U), one student is employed as a laboratory technician in the physical science department at the North Carolina School of Science and Math, two students applied to master’s programs in engineering, one student is attending graduate school in Chemistry at NC State University and one student is currently looking for engineering based employment.

The students learned computational and experimental techniques, including processing and presenting data.

Products:

During the grant period, 11 papers were published by the COHERENT collaboration including the PI.  Students, Abasi Brown and Erem Ujah earned authorship status by providing a substantive contribution to the NaI detector system for at least one year. Abasi Brown who constructed and calibrated the muon veto panels for the 185-kg NaI experiment (NaIvE-185) is included in the Science paper from 2017 announcing the first observance of CEvNS. Erem Ujah who contributed to the characterization, construction and calibration of the multi-ton NaI detector array, is an author on recent papers including the observance of CEvNS in liquid argon.

8 conference posters were presented by students and 7 conference talks were presented by the PI.

Two successful NSF follow-on proposals were produced. "MRI Consortium: Development of an Array of Germanium Detectors for COHERENT at the Spallation Neutron Source" to Duke University with an NCCU subaward to PI Markoff.  Duke PI Scholberg was the mentor for Markoff under the RIA grant. This grant pays for the germanium detectors, muon panels, and electronics needed for the new experiment. "Research at an Undergraduate Institution: Neutrino Scattering Experiments at the Spallation Neutron Source" PI Markoff. This proposal supports the PI and students to continue working on the NaI and the germanium detector arrays for CEvNS measurements and other neutrino scattering experiments located at the SNS.

Broader Impacts:

Right before the pandemic, the PI trained in the regional IMPACTS program run by the North Carolina Morehead Planetarium outreach group.  In this program, the PI learned techniques in engaging audiences in science topics.  One program focused on working with middle school students while another program focused on the public of high-school and adult ages. During the pandemic in 2020, the PI engaged in virtual after-school visits with grade school children. The PI participated in the SciMATCH program in Spring 2021 providing virtual visits to a regional North Carolina public middle-school science classes associated with one teacher.

The PI has been developing a series of lectures on the application of nuclear physics techniques to study art and artifacts, archeology, and forensics.  Various versions of these talks were presented to the public at the NC Museum of Natural History Science Café, to high-school students in summer programs at Duke and at NCCU, and to undergraduate students in summer programs at Duke.  These talks include an emphasis on the interconnectedness of science and culture.
